action:
Submit annual emissions inventory for all PBR-authorized equipment. Include actual hours of operation, fuel usage, and calculated emissions for NOx, CO, VOC, and PM.

Recordkeeping: Maintain records of monthly operational hours, fuel consumption, and emission calculations for each piece of equipment.

Conduct visual inspection of all three emergency generators to verify proper operation and absence of visible emissions during testing.

Recordkeeping: Document inspection date, inspector name, any observations of smoke or abnormal operation, and corrective actions taken.

Exercise all emergency generators for minimum 30 minutes under load to verify readiness and proper operation per manufacturer specifications.

Recordkeeping: Log date, duration, load percentage, fuel usage, and any maintenance issues identified during testing.

Calculate and record monthly operational hours for all emergency generators. Verify compliance with 500 hours/year limit (emergency use + maintenance).

Recordkeeping: Maintain monthly logs showing date, time, duration, and reason for operation (emergency, testing, maintenance). Track rolling 12-month total.

Renew PBR registration for storage tanks (<40,000 gallons). Submit PBR Form with updated tank specifications, stored materials, and true vapor pressure data.

Recordkeeping: Maintain copy of current registration, material safety data sheets, and vapor pressure calculations.

Inspect both storage tanks for proper sealing, absence of leaks, and structural integrity. Verify pressure/vacuum relief valves are functional.

Recordkeeping: Document inspection date, findings, condition of seals and valves, and any repairs or maintenance performed.

Monitor and record operational parameters for both natural gas engines including hours of operation, fuel flow rates, and stack temperatures.

Recordkeeping: Maintain quarterly logs of engine runtime, maintenance activities, and any performance issues affecting emissions.

Perform manufacturer-recommended annual maintenance on all natural gas engines including air filter replacement, spark plug inspection/replacement, and oil/filter changes.

Recordkeeping: Log maintenance date, technician, parts replaced, and post-maintenance operational checks.

Inspect vapor recovery unit for proper operation. Verify pressure gauges are reading within normal range and no visible damage to piping or connections.

Recordkeeping: Document monthly inspection results including pressure readings, any odors detected, and condition of equipment.

Calculate quarterly VOC emissions from storage tanks based on throughput and vapor pressure data using EPA AP-42 emission factors.

Recordkeeping: Maintain quarterly records of throughput volumes, vapor pressure measurements, calculated emissions, and methodology used.

Conduct annual training for all operators on PBR requirements, equipment operation, emission control practices, and emergency procedures.

Recordkeeping: Maintain training records including date, attendees, topics covered, and trainer information.

Service all emergency generators including battery testing, coolant level checks, belt inspection, and load bank testing to verify performance under load.

Recordkeeping: Log service date, technician, test results, battery voltage readings, and any deficiencies corrected.

Calibrate all fuel flow meters and hour meters on engines and generators to ensure accurate recordkeeping of fuel consumption and operating hours.

Recordkeeping: Maintain calibration certificates, before/after readings, and technician certifications.

Record monthly fuel usage for all engines and generators. Calculate emissions using manufacturer emission factors and verify compliance with PBR limits.

Recordkeeping: Log monthly fuel consumption by equipment, calculated NOx/CO/VOC/PM emissions, and comparison to permit limits.

Conduct LDAR (Leak Detection and Repair) inspection of all piping, valves, and connections associated with vapor recovery unit using portable VOC detector.

Recordkeeping: Document inspection date, instrument used, any leaks detected (location and concentration), and repairs completed.
